data.Name: Alluvial
data.Description: The Alluvial depositional environments includes all deposits laid by and in association with, rivers. These account for a significant proportion of modern continental systems and occur in all climatic settings. This depositional environment includes deposits laid down in alluvial fans, fluvial channels, overbank settings and the fill of a variety of incised valleys, cut into bedrock or into older alluvium

data.Name: Erg
data.Description: Erg is used to describe large wind blown sand-seas. The Erg environment is used to capture all of the systems that are associated with aeolian processes, such as dunes, sandsheets and interdune sabkhas. The term is preferred over "desert" because deserts may include significant fluvial systems. The Erg environment occurs primarily within the arid climate and also to a lesser extent in the polar setting.

data.Name: Lacustrine
data.Description: Lacustrine deposits away from the lake shoreline are dominantly mudstones. Their detailed character will depending upon the nature of the climate and the depth of the lake. Lakes are commonly stratified and deep water systems will often be very organic rich and my produce source rocks. Lakes in more arid climates may include evaporites and carbonates. Cyclicity is common. Small turbidites may be present.

data.Name: GlacigenicUndiff
data.Description: Land terminating ice sheet landsystem. Undifferentiated related to sub-glacial/pro-glacial.

data.Name: GlacigenicSubGlacial
data.Description: Glacial erosion and deposition is responsible for the formation of a unique landform and sediment assemblage. Processes below the glacier ice. It can be divided into slow and fast moving ice

data.Name: GlacigenicProGlacial
data.Description: Glaciers close by in the source area. Glacier has no direct influence of ice contact on sediment deposition.

data.Name: Delta
data.Description: Deltas are defined as those depositional features, both subaerial and subaqueous, that forms when a river enters a still standing body of water like an ocean or a lake. In many instances the deposition of fluvial sediments is strongly modified by marine forces such as waves, currents and tides, and depositional features found in deltas therefore display a high degree of variability. A delta should, by definition, prograde. They are typically classified according to the main control on deposition, which is a combination of river, wave, and tidal processes, depending on the strength of each. A significant deltaic accumulation necessarily requires the existence of a river system carrying substantial quantities of clastic sediment from an inland drainage basin to the coast, where the deposits form the delta plain or delta slope. All deltas have at least one common feature: a river supplying clastic sediment to the coast and adjacent shelf more rapidly than it can be dispersed by marine processes, and therefore a prograding sedimentary succession forms. A delta may be divided into a delta top, delta front, and prodelta. The delta top generally can be subdivided into upper and lower delta plain. The upper delta plain is existing above the area of significant tidal or marine influences. The lower delta plain lies within the realm of river-marine interaction and extends landward from the low-tide mark to the limit of tidal influence. The subaqueous part of the delta is called delta front and is that part of the delta lying below the low-tide water level. The delta front is most commonly characterized by a seaward fining of sediments, sands and coarser elastics being deposited near the river mouths and finer grained sediment dispersing farther seaward. The most distal part of the delta is called the prodelta, dominated by even finer sediments. As the delta prograde, a vertical profile will therefore show an upward coarsening trend.

data.Name: FluvioDeltaic
data.Description: River dominated deltas are progradational shallow marine systems dominated by fluvial processes. When deposited into shallow waters, deltas are dominated by mouth bars. Grainsize is a key control on delta front geometry and reservoir behaviour. They are the most common form of delta. River dominated deltas deposited into a deep (10-100 m) receiving basins are dominated by bedload processes which produce steep clinoforms. They commonly occur in shelf edge settings, but may also occur in a fjords and tectonically active basins.

data.Name: WaveInfluencedDelta
data.Description: Fluvial deltas that are modified by wave processes. The fluvial system deposits its sediment load at the mouth of the river and then some of the sediment is locally reworked by wave action. Mouthbars modified by longshore sediment transport due to wave action. Wave influenced delta make excellent reservoirs although there are subtitles associated with them that can be important to understand

data.Name: TideInfluencedDelta
data.Description: Fluvial dominated delta which are tidally influenced occur in a variety of ancient and modern settings. Such delta systems are similar to their fluvial counterparts but include a strong tidal component. The distributary channels are funnel shaped and there are tidal creeks cutting through the delta plain. They commonly occur in areas where the tidal range is meso- to macro-tidal.

data.Name: TideDominatedDelta
data.Description: Progradational, deltaic systems dominated by tidal processes are rare, because a very strong fluvial component is required for a delta to form. Furthermore a degree of topographic embayment is required for a strong tidal range to develop while most deltas occur as protrusions into a marine basin. Tide dominated deltas tend to occur on wide continental shelves within systems that are partially confined by very large topographic features.

data.Name: WaveDominatedDelta
data.Description: Estuaries form at the interface between continental and marine environments.

data.Name: Estuary
data.Description: Estuaries form at the interface between continental and marine environments. It is the seaward portion of a drowned river valley which receives sediment from both fluvial and marine sources. An estuary may be affected by tide, wave and river processes and is defined as extending from the landward limit of tidal influence to the seaward limit of coastal influence. Within the estuary, the seaward portion of the valley is filled with marine sediments. Estuaries are fundamentally transgressive in nature. They are classified with two end members; tide-dominated estuary and storm-dominated estuary. In tide-dominated estuaries, the mouth of the estuary is kept open by strong tidal currents. The center of the estuary are dominated by sand-rich tidal channels and bars, whereas the margins tend to be muddy tidal flats. In wave-dominated estuaries, the mouth of the estuary is partly closed by a wave-generated barrier island. The estuary central basin is situated in area behind the barrier, and is commonly filled with fine-grained mud. At the head of the estuary, a bayhead delta forms. The base of estuaries are commonly marked by an erosional unconformity formed by fluvial erosion. In a complete, transgressive estuarine succession, this surface is overlain by fluvial deposits, which are in turn overlain by tide-dominated sediments.

data.Name: TideDominatedEstuary
data.Description: Estuaries are coastal embayments, either formed by structurally generated topography or the transgressive flooding of eroded river valleys. Estuaries are zones with a mixed marine and fresh water influence on process and fauna. Tide dominated estuaries occur where the embayment enters a marine system with a moderate to high tidal range. It should be noted that Ainsworth et al (2010) highlight that all estuaries are dominated, at least in the areal distribution of processes and therefore refer to them as Fw (and Ft in the case of tidal estuaries). For the purpose of this work we have preferred to stick to the more traditional classification which we feel is in more common usage.

data.Name: WaveDominatedEstuary
data.Description: Estuaries are coastal embayments, either formed by structurally generated topography or the transgressive flooding of eroded river valleys. Estuaries are zones with a mixed marine and fresh water influence on process and fauna. Wave dominated estuaries occur where the embayment enters a marine system with moderate to strong wave influence and a low tidal range. It should be noted that Ainsworth et al (2010) highlight that all estuaries are dominated, at least in the areal distribution of processes and therefore refer to them as Fw (and Ft in the case of tidal estuaries). For the purpose of this work we have preferred to stick to the more traditional classification which we feel is in more common usage

data.Name: TideDominatedCoast
data.Description: Tide-dominated coasts are best developed in areas where the tidal range is significant and where currents are sufficiently strong to impact the depositional environment or drive local marine circulation. At such coasts, strong tidal currents act to redistribute coastal sediment due to falling and rising tidal currents. These currents are often orientated perpendicular to the trend of the coastline. Within a tide-dominated coast, the occurrence of supratidal, intertidal and subtidal zones are common The aerial extent of the tidal zones varies greatly among different coastal areas depending on the tidal range and the type of coastline. Coastlines may be embayed (estuaries and lagoons), lobate (deltas) or linear. Within linear, tide-dominated coastlines, upward coarsening tidal flats are common. Macrotidal conditions favor the development of extensive tidal flats, but they are also common in mesotidal to microtidal coasts. Tidal flats are usually dissected by tidal creek systems. These are either sand- or mud-filled.

data.Name: TidalShorelineNonDeltaic
data.Description: Non-deltaic tidal shorelines occur in areas of high tidal range and limited wave action, away from fluvial entry points. Tidal processes are dominant and the shoreline is sculptured by the twice daily incoming and outgoing water. The setting is characterised by extensive, inter-tidal mudflats and salt marshes which are cut by networks branching tidal channels. The sub-tidal zone lies to the seaward side of the low tide line and commonly contains sand bars and sand flats. Overall tidal shorelines generate heterolithic and challenging reservoirs.

data.Name: WaveInfluencedTidalShoreline
data.Description: Shorelines that have a large tidal range and also face large open marine basins so that wave activity is also important. Given that tidal processes are dominant the systems includes a similar range of tidal sediment to the Tide dominated shoreline, however the wave modification tends to produce inter tidal zones that are more sand dominated. In addition sub-tidal bars are modified by waves and storm processes and occur interfingering with shoreface deposits.

data.Name: BarrierIsland
data.Description: Barrier Islands are common features in modern, transgressive wave dominated coastlines. The barrier is a linear feature with a shoreface on the seaward side and a lagoon on the landward side. Barriers typically migrate in a landward direction by washover of sediment, from the beach into the lagoon during storms. Continued sea-level rise is required to maintain the barrier, else the lagoon will be filled with sediment. The process of landward migration is termed barrier roll-over and results in very little deposition in the rock record. Barriers may also be preserved if a rapid transgression "drowns" the barrier before it has sufficient time to migrate. Barrier and barrier like systems can also form by longshore migration of sediment forming spits that subsequently become detached. In such cases these may be part of a progradational shoreline system.

data.Name: TideInfluencedBarrierIsland
data.Description: Barrier Islands are common features in modern, transgressive wave dominated coastlines. The barrier is a linear feature with a shoreface on the seaward side and a lagoon on the landward side. In systems with a meso-tidal range, the barrier island will be cut be frequent tidal inlet channels that allow the rising and falling tide to enter and leave the lagoon. As with wave dominated barrier islands they typically migrate in a landward direction by the landward migration of sediment into the lagoon by washover and deposition in flood tidal deltas. Continued sea-level rise is required to maintain the barrier, else the lagoon will be filled with sediment. The process of landward migration is termed barrier roll-over and results in very little deposition in the rock record. Barriers may be preserved if a rapid transgression "drowns" the barrier before it has sufficient time to migrate. Barrier and barrier like systems can also form by longshore migration of sediment forming spits that subsequently become detached. In such cases these may be part of a progradational shoreline system.

data.Name: Bay
data.Description: Bay fill deposits are standing, shallow bodies of water found in the lower delta plain, broken off the main distributary system. The upper delta plain lies on a floodplain found at the mouth of a river, the lower lies above the upper delta front. The grain sizes are typically interbedded fine to medium-coarse sands, silts, and muds, washed in from the main distributaries.

data.Name: Shoreface
data.Description: The shoreface is the sloped surface that connects to the basin plain from the coast. It is the area between the shoreline at low-tide and the subaqueous basin floor. The shoreface can be divided into the upper- and lower-shoreface. In the upper, shallower section, the sediment has a stronger wave influence. There is less influence on the lower shoreface, where finer materials are deposited

data.Name: FluvialInfluencedShoreface
data.Description: Wave-dominated Fluvial-influenced (Wf) shorelines, are similar to wave dominated shorelines with straight and parallel shoreface deposits with beach ridges. The minor fluvial influence does not generate a protruding delta and is often heavily modified the wave action. If the waves are able to redistribute the sediment supplied by the river more quickly than it is transported to the coastline, then the system can be said to have high wave effectiveness and low fluvial effectiveness. The determination of high versus low wave and fluvial effectiveness in the ancient relies on knowledge of the paleogeography of an area. If an area of coastline is open to a large body of water or an ocean, a high probability exists that it will have a high wave effectiveness. However, if a body of water is sheltered from oceanic waves by a headland, an island, or by rugose coastal morphology, then it may be considered to have a probability of high fluvial effectiveness and low wave effectiveness. If evidence for ancient rivers can be found in the rock record, then the area can be said to potentially have relatively high fluvial effectiveness. However, fluvial process dominance in these circumstances is not always the case as wave processes can still redistribute sediment supplied by the rivers, and hence waves can become the dominant depositional process. Alternatively, if paleogeographic information is available as to the size of the fluvial drainage areas, predictions of wave versus fluvial effectiveness can also be made on this basis. Relatively large drainage basins would have a higher probability of producing high fluvial effectiveness at the coastline.

data.Name: TideInfluencedShoreface
data.Description: Tide influenced shoreface successions are similar in geometry and nature to more simple wave dominated shorefaces with the exception that they occur in areas with higher tidal ranges (meso to macro) and the upper part of the progradational succession is typically much thicker.

data.Name: Shelf
data.Description: The shallow marine shelf is the area that lies in relatively shallow water seaward of the various shoreline types. In wave and fluvial dominated systems the shelf is typically mud dominated as it lies beneath mean storm wave base. The region may however receive that is introduced by larger storms. Such shelves are also local cross cut by sub-aqueous channels which are generated by geostrophic (storm related) or hyperpycnal (river related) currents. A key aspect is the width of the shelf which will have a fundamental impact in the nature of the processes at the shoreline. Wide shelves reduce wave action and enhance the relative important of tidal and fluvial processes, while narrow shells are typically associated with more wave dominated coastlines.

data.Name: GlacigenicSubaqueous
data.Description: Lacustrine / marine terminating ice sheet landsystem

data.Name: GlacigenicProGlacialSubaqueous
data.Description: Subaqueous deposits close to a glacier. Glacier has no direct influence of ice contact on sediment deposition.

data.Name: UpperSlope
data.Description: The upper slope is the upper portion of the continental slope, below the shelf-edge break and is typically cross-cut by gullies and canyons. Traditionally considered an area of starvation, bypass and erosion without significant coarse-grained sedimentation. If the upper slope has a steep gradient and there is a significant sea-level fall below the shelf edge, sand deposition occurs mainly as coarse-grained lags within canyons, perched depositional lobes or within channel-levee complexes. Lack of canyons on the upper slope together with little or no sea-level fall below the shelf edge allows for sand-prone accretion of the shelf margin and the development of slope clinoforms.

data.Name: LowerSlope
data.Description: The lower slope is the lower portion of the continental slope, above the toe of slope. The gradient change from slope to basin floor depends on tectonic setting and sediment accumulation. Shelf edge erosion and bypass favor lower slope and basin floor deposition while shelf edge deposition. and accretion usually lead to starvation of the lower slope and basin floor. Channel-levee complexes and proximal submarine fans are common depositional environments on the lower slope. Many large-volume discoveries to date occur in the toe-of-slope environment in graded passive margins.

data.Name: SlopeApron
data.Description: Slope aprons are tapering wedges occurring at the base of slope, or on intra-slope topography healing slope breaks. The wedge has an onlap termination up dip, and gradually thin away from the slope on which they deposit.

data.Name: PondedBasin
data.Description: Ponded basins are submarine depositional lows effective in trapping and accumulating sediments and are typically occurring on a stepped or topographically complex slope. Gravity flows entering the basin are fully confined by the basin margins. In order for flow ponding to take place the confining basin must be completely surrounded by topographic barriers that are sufficiently high to prevent any part of the gravity flow to surmount and efficiently trapping all sediments within the pond. In core this can be observed as an unusually thick mudstone cap above each sandstone bed, thick sandstone beds dominate and there are complex flow reflection structures within the bed.

data.Name: Injectite
data.Description: Injectites are sedimentary dykes, where fluidised sediment exploits a weakness in the carrier bed and cross-cuts the sedimentary strata. Injectites can occur passively due to water, wind, and gravity, or due to overpressuring from another source. Injectites can be a few metres to kilometres thick. Injectites are most commonly sandstone but can be muds, siltstone, salts, shale, or carbonate material precipitating in a rock fracture. They are more commonly near-vertical, as opposed to sheet injections, which are bed concordant or horizontal.

data.Name: ShelfEdge
data.Description: The shelf edge, also termed shelf margin, is the roll-over zone between the flat-lying continental shelf and the steeper continental slope. Defining the shelf edge is essential because it separates areas dominated by shallow marine depositional processes from areas dominated by gravity driven processes. The shape of the shelf edge varies depending on depositional setting; active or passive margin setting and graded or ungraded basin profile. There is a continuous construction and degradation of the shelf edge zone, primarily driven by sediment transport across and along the shelf, sediment accumulation on the shelf edge and sea-level changes. Shelf edge deltas play a critical role in shelf margin accretion and deep-water sediment delivery and sea-level fall below the shelf edge is in many cases crucial for basin floor fan development.

data.Name: BasinFloor
data.Description: Deposition on the basin floor across much of the oceans is in the form of hemipelagic and pelagic muds, deposited from suspension. Locally deposition of course material occurs from turbidity flows and to a lesser extent semi-permanent bottom currents. The basin floor is a low relief plain which covers much of the oceans. In passive continental margins, the basin floor occurs at the base of slope at significant water depths (>2 km) and turbidite systems are typically unconfined (i.e. smaller than the basin).

data.Name: Subaerial
data.Description: Comprises all carbonate deposits in subaerial settings, such at e.g. travertine and tufa that are originated from mineral springs. These are often locally developed and volumetrically small and this carbonate precipitation is a shared product of physicochemical and microbiological biomediation processes.

data.Name: LacustrineCarbonatePlatformUndifferentiated
data.Description: A sedimentary body which possesses topographic relief, and is composed of autochthonous calcareous lacustrine deposits. The large-scale morphologies of carbonate platforms based on depositional slope angle profile. Lacustrine deposits can be a product of either biological, microbial or physico-chemical processes.

data.Name: LacustrineRampUndifferentiated
data.Description: A gentle slope in a lacustrine carbonate depositional system extends from the lake shoreline, or a platform surface, to the adjacent deeper lake. The angle of slope is commonly much less than 1° (although there may be steeper dips locally) and which may be either be inherited or constructed

data.Name: LacustrineRampInnerRamp
data.Description: The zone of lacustrine ramp deposition between upper shoreface (beach or lagoonal shoreline) and "fair-weather" wave base. The lake floor in this zone experiences almost constant wind and wave agitation.

data.Name: LacustrineRampMidRamp
data.Description: The zone of lacustrine ramp deposition between "fair-weather" wave base and "storm" wave base, in which bottom sediment is less frequently reworked by waves."

data.Name: LacustrineRampOuterRamp
data.Description: The zone of lacustrine ramp deposition below normal "storm" wave base, characterized by mudstone/low energy deposits and few reworked transported beds."

data.Name: LacustrineShelfUndifferentiated
data.Description: A lacustrine carbonate depositional system which develops perceptible constructional relief above the lake floor (tens to thousands of metres). The transition from shallow water to basin is marked by a distinct break in slope and occurs over a relatively short distance (metres to a few kilometres). Slope angles vary from around 1° to almost vertical. In addition, a shelf can be rimmed or non-rimmed, depending upon whether an elevated "lip" is present landward of the shelf break (i.e. the break in slope from relatively flat to inclined).

data.Name: LacustrineShelfInterior
data.Description: The zone of a lacustrine carbonate shelf with wide facies belts that extents from the shore to the platform margin that includes the shore zone complex (the area around the actual shoreline or islands on isolated platforms, which can be low- or high-energy) and the low or high energy environments that exists from the shelf margin to the shoreline.

data.Name: LacustrineShelfMargin
data.Description: A higher-energy zone of lacustrine shallow water sedimentation indicating the distinct break in slope profile from a flat platform top to a steeper inclined platform slope. The area is often characterised by buildup growth and/or shoals.

data.Name: LacustrineShelfSlopeUndifferentiated
data.Description: The slope is the outer part of the lacustrine shelf platform with distinct gradient, connecting the platform shelf top with the basin. Shelf slopes can range in morphology from gentle gradients to steep cliffs and is best subdivided into facies tracts according to distinctive deposits, processes, and architecture. These differences in gradient are influenced by the sediment budget. This depositional environment acts as sink for excess carbonate sediment: most of the sediment produced in the lagoon and reef is transported by various processes and accumulates in the slope, with an inclination depending on the grain size of sediments resulting in narrow facies belts. If gradient becomes to steep, slope areas can be bypassed by sediments generated on the platform. To encompass this heterogeneity, carbonate-slope deposits are subdivided into three deposit types: 1. Debris deposits; 2. Grain-dominated deposits; and 3. Mud-dominated deposits

data.Name: LacustrineShelfUpperSlope
data.Description: The proximal part of the slope (the outer part of the shelf platform, connecting the platform shelf top with the basin) containing abundant reworked sediment, often in the form of debris flows (mega-breccias) where slopes are steep."

data.Name: LacustrineShelfLowerSlope
data.Description: The more distal part of the slope (the outer part of the shelf platform, connecting the platform shelf top with the basin) containing a broad area of finer-grained re-deposited sediments, with cut-and-fill channel features

data.Name: LacustrineShelfToeOfSlope
data.Description: The zone at the base or bottom of a slope at the point where the ground surface abruptly changes to a significantly flatter grade (seaward transition from inclined to flat-lying strata). Sedimentation is characterized by in situ pelagic sedimentation combined with different degrees of re-worked material transported from the platform.

data.Name: LacustrineIntraPlatformBasin
data.Description: Intra-platform basins (moats, inshore basins, shelf basins, differentiated shelf, and deep-water lagoons or others) are depressions of varying sizes and shapes that occur within tectonically passive and regionally extensive lacustrine carbonate shelves. Intra-platform basins grade laterally and downdip (seaward) into shallow-water carbonates of the regional shelf, and are largely filled by fine-grained sediments having attributes of shallow- and deeper water sedimentation.

data.Name: LacustrineBasinal
data.Description: Deposition on the basin floor across much of the deeper lake is in the form of pelagic muds deposited from suspension. Locally deposition of coarse material occurs from turbidity flows. The basin floor is a low relief plain which covers much of the deeper lake.

data.Name: CarbonatePlatformUndifferentiated
data.Description: A sedimentary body which possesses topographic relief, and is composed of autochthonous calcareous marine deposits. The large-scale morphologies of carbonate platforms based on depositional slope angle profile.

data.Name: RampUndifferentiated
data.Description: A gentle slope in a marine carbonate depositional system extends from the shoreline, or a platform surface, to the adjacent basin. The angle of slope is commonly much less than 1° (although there may be steeper dips locally) and which may be either be inherited or constructed

data.Name: RampInnerRamp
data.Description: The zone of marine ramp deposition between upper shoreface (beach or lagoonal shoreline) and fair-weather wave base. The sea floor in this zone experiences almost constant wave agitation. It includes both protected/subaerial part (intertidal/supratidal zones with sabkha, tidal flats and narrow restricted lagoons) and wave dominated high energy shoreline (often dominated by grainstone complexes and tidal channel complexes). It is dominated by sand shoals or organic barriers and shoreface deposits and back-barrier peritidal areas.

data.Name: RampMidRamp
data.Description: The zone of marine ramp deposition between fair-weather wave base and storm wave base, in which bottom sediment is frequently reworked by storm waves and swells." Dominating facies are bioclastic/pelloidal wackestone to mudstone with grainstone storm deposits and occasionally algal mud mounds.

data.Name: ShelfUndifferentiated
data.Description: A marine carbonate depositional system which develops perceptible constructional relief above the sea floor (tens to thousands of metres). The transition from shallow water to basin is marked by a distinct break in slope and occurs over a relatively short distance (metres to a few kilometres). Slope angles vary from a degree or so to almost vertical. In addition, a shelf can be rimmed or non-rimmed, depending upon whether an elevated "lip" is present landward of the shelf break (i.e. the break in slope from relatively flat to inclined).

data.Name: ShelfInterior
data.Description: The zone of a marine carbonate shelf with wide facies belts that extents from the shore to the platform margin that includes the shore zone complex (the area around the actual shoreline (or islands on isolated platforms), which can be low- or high-energy) and the lagoon (a zone of peritidal-subtidal environments that exists from the shelf margin to the shoreline)

data.Name: ShelfMargin
data.Description: A high-energy zone of marine shallow water sedimentation indicating the distinct break in slope profile from a flat platform top to a steeper inclined platform slope. The area is often characterised by reef sediments and/or sand shoals. In case the margin has significant relief compared to the platform interior, it is called a rimmed platform.

data.Name: RampOuterRamp
data.Description: The zone of marine ramp deposition below normal storm wave base, characterized by mudstone deposition and few storm beds."

data.Name: ShelfSlopeUndifferentiated
data.Description: The slope is the outer part of the marine shelf platform with distinct gradient, connecting the platform shelf top with the basin. Shelf slopes can range in morphology from gentle gradients to steep cliffs and is best subdivided into facies tracts according to distinctive deposits, processes, and architecture. These differences in gradient are influenced by the sediment budget. This depositional environment acts as sink for excess carbonate sediment: most of the sediment produced in the lagoon and reef is transported by various processes and accumulates in the slope, with an inclination depending on the grain size of sediments resulting in narrow facies belts. If gradient becomes to steep, slope areas can be bypassed by sediments generated on the platform. To encompass this heterogeneity, carbonate slope deposits are subdivided into three deposit types: 1. Debris deposits; 2. Grain-dominated deposits; and 3. Mud-dominated deposits

data.Name: ShelfUpperSlope
data.Description: The proximal part of the slope (i.e. the outer part of the shelf platform, connecting the platform shelf top with the basin) containing abundant reworked sediment, often in the form of debris flows (mega-breccias) where slopes are steep."

data.Name: ShelfLowerSlope
data.Description: The more distal part of the slope (i.e. the outer part of the shelf platform, connecting the platform shelf top with the basin) containing a broad area of finer-grained re-deposited sediments, at times interbedded with in-situ pelagic sedimentation. The lower slopes are often characterized by cut-and-fill channel features.

data.Name: ShelfToeOfSlope
data.Description: The zone at the base or bottom of a slope at the point where the ground surface abruptly changes to a significantly flatter grade (seaward transition from inclined to flat-lying strata). Sedimentation is characterized by in situ pelagic sedimentation combined with different degrees of re-worked material transported from the platform.

data.Name: ShelfIntraPlatformBasin
data.Description: Intra-platform basins (moats, inshore basins, shelf basins, differentiated shelf, and deep-water lagoons of others) are depressions of varying sizes and shapes that occur within tectonically passive and regionally extensive carbonate shelves. Intra-platform basins grade laterally and downdip (seaward) into shallow-water carbonates of the regional shelf, are separated from the open marine basin by the shelf margin, and are largely filled by fine-grained subtidal (commonly organic-rich) sediments having attributes of shallow- and deeper water sedimentation.

data.Name: Basinal
data.Description: Deposition on the basin floor across much of the oceans is in the form of hemipelagic and pelagic muds, deposited from suspension. Locally deposition of coarse material occurs from turbidity flows and to a lesser extent semi-permanent bottom currents. The basin floor is a low relief plain which covers much of the oceans. In passive continental margins, the basin floor occurs at the base of slope at significant water depths (>2 km) and turbidite systems are typically unconfined (i.e. smaller than the basin). The deep-water (pelagic) carbonate factory can be present in basinal settings. Sediments that are dominated by calcareous nannofossils (dominantly coccoliths and foraminifera) are known as calcareous ooze and will lithify to form limestone (commonly chalk)". Sediments that are dominated by siliceous nannofossils (diatoms and radiolaria) are known as siliceous ooze, and will lithify to form chert

data.Name: ContinentalSubaerialVolcanicSequenceUndifferentiated
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of undifferentiated volcanic rocks - solidified in subaerial conditions within a continental setting

data.Name: ContinentalSubaerialLavaField(FissureFed)
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of volcanic rocks - solidified in subaerial conditions within a continental setting in the form of wide-spread lava field

data.Name: ContinentalSubaerialVolcano(PointSourced)
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of volcanic rocks - solidified in subaerial conditions within a continental setting  in the form of point sourced eruption centres

data.Name: ContinentalSubaerialPyroclastic
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of pyroclastic rocks - solidified in subaerial conditions within a continental setting - A pyroclastic flow is a dense, fast-moving flow of solidified lava pieces, volcanic ash, and hot gases. It occurs as part of certain volcanic eruptions. A pyroclastic flow is extremely hot, burning anything in its path. It may move at speeds as high as 200 m/s.  Pyroclastic fall is a uniform deposit of material which has been ejected from a volcanic eruption or plume such as an ash fall or tuff.

data.Name: ContinentalSubaerialVolcaniclastic(Reworked)
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of reworked volcanic rocks -  in subaerial conditions within a continental setting -Volcaniclastics are materials composed of broken fragments (clasts) of volcanic rock. These encompass all clastic volcanic materials, regardless of what process fragmented the rock, how it was subsequently transported, what environment it was deposited in, or whether nonvolcanic material is mingled with the volcanic clasts.

data.Name: ContinentalSubaqueousVolcanicSequenceUndifferentiated
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of undifferentiated volcanic rocks - solidified in subaqueous conditions within a continental setting. This typically happens in local lake and river systems

data.Name: TransitionalSubaerialVolcanicSequenceUndifferentiated
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of undifferentiated volcanic rocks - solidified in subaerial conditions within a transitional marine/shallow marine setting

data.Name: TransitionalSubaqueousVolcanicSequenceUndifferentiated
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of undifferentiated volcanic rocks - solidified in subaqueous conditions within a transitional marine/shallow marine setting

data.Name: TransitionalSubaqueousLavaDelta
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of volcanic rocks - solidified in subaqueous conditions within a transitional marine/shallow marine setting - Lava deltas, similar to river deltas form wherever sufficient sub-aerial flows of lava enter standing bodies of water. The lava cools and breaks up as it encounters the water, with the resulting fragments filling in the adjacent seabed topography such that the flow can move further offshore sub-aerially. Lava deltas are generally associated with large-scale, effusive type basaltic volcanism.

data.Name: TransitionalVolcano(PointSourced)
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of volcanic rocks - solidified in subaqueous conditions within a transitional marine/shallow marine setting -  in the form of point sourced eruption centres

data.Name: TransitionalSubaqueousPyroclastic
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of pyroclastic  rocks - solidified in subaqueous conditions within a transitional marine/shallow marine setting -  A pyroclastic flow is a dense, fast-moving flow of solidified lava pieces, volcanic ash, and hot gases. It occurs as part of certain volcanic eruptions. A pyroclastic flow can interact with a body of water to form a large amount of mud, which can then continue to flow downhill as a lahar.  Pyroclastic fall is a uniform deposit of material which has been ejected from a volcanic eruption or plume such as an ash fall or tuff.

data.Name: TransitionalSubaqueousVolcaniclastic(Reworked)
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of reworked volcanic rocks -  in subaqueous conditions within a transitional marine/shallow marine setting -Volcaniclastics are materials composed of broken fragments (clasts) of volcanic rock. These encompass all clastic volcanic materials, regardless of what process fragmented the rock, how it was subsequently transported, what environment it was deposited in, or whether nonvolcanic material is mingled with the volcanic clasts.

data.Name: MarineSubaqueousVolcanicSequenceUndifferentiated
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of undifferentiated volcanic rocks - solidified in subaqueous conditions within a marine/deeper marine setting

data.Name: MarineSubaqueousVolcano(PointSourced)
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of volcanic rocks - solidified in subaqueous conditions within a marine/deeper marine setting in the form of point sourced eruption centres

data.Name: MarineSubaqueousPyroclastic
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of pyroclastic  rocks - solidified in subaqueous conditions within a marine/deeper marine setting -  A pyroclastic flow is a dense, fast-moving flow of solidified lava pieces, volcanic ash, and hot gases. It occurs as part of certain volcanic eruptions with hot gas-rich pyroclastic flows, mass-flows which resulted from the transformation of gassupported flows into water-supported ones

data.Name: MarineSubaqueousVolcaniclastic(Reworked)
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of reworked volcanic rocks -  in subaqueous conditions within a   marine/deeper marine setting -Volcaniclastics are materials composed of broken fragments (clasts) of volcanic rock. These encompass all clastic volcanic materials, regardless of what process fragmented the rock, how it was subsequently transported, what environment it was deposited in, or whether nonvolcanic material is mingled with the volcanic clasts. it includes secondary mass-flows carrying redeposited lava fragments and pyroclastic debris
data.(COMPANY: insert comment): Removed trailing dot, which is not supported in Azure record ids.

data.Name: IntrusiveUndifferentiated
data.Description: Depositional environment composed of undifferentiated intrusive rocks - Solidification into rock occurs below the surface as intrusive rocks

data.Name: IntrusiveMinorSheetsStocksShallow
data.Description: Shallow intrusive depositional environment - a stock is an igneous intrusion that has a surface exposure of less than 100 square kilometers, differing from batholiths only in being smaller. A stock has a discordant relationship with the rocks that it intrudes.

data.Name: IntrusiveMinorSheetsStocksDeep
data.Description: Deep intrusive depositional environment - a stock is an igneous intrusion that has a surface exposure of less than 100 square kilometres, differing from batholiths only in being smaller. A stock has a discordant relationship with the rocks that it intrudes.

data.Name: IntrusiveMajorComplexBatholith
data.Description: A batholite is a large mass of deep intrusive igneous rock (also called plutonic rock), larger than 100 square kilometres in area, that forms from cooled magma deep in the Earth's crust. Batholiths are almost always made mostly of felsic or intermediate rock types, such as granite, quartz monzonite, or diorite

data.Name: HydrothermalVentComplex
data.Description: A hydrothermal vent complex is a fissure on the seafloor or at surface from which geothermally heated water discharges. Hydrothermal vents are commonly found near volcanically active places, areas where tectonic plates are moving apart at spreading centers, ocean basins, and hotspots. The upper termination of the inclined shallow sheets/stocks is often associated with small craters and cones that erupted at the paleosurface, suggesting a relationship between saucer-sills and vent complexes. The vent complexes can be of both hydrothermal (phreatic) and magmatic origin. Hydrothermal deposits are rocks and mineral ore deposits formed by the action of hydrothermal vents.

data.Name: MetamorphicUndifferentiated
data.Description: Undifferentiated metamorphic rocks

data.Name: ContactMetamorphism
data.Description: Shallow, local metamorphism. Hornfels

data.Name: RegionalMetamorphism
data.Description: Mid to lower crustal, e.g. greenschist, amphibolite, granulite, eclogite

data.Name: EvaporiteUndifferentiated
data.Description: Evaporites - undifferentiated depositional environment

data.Name: PlatformEvaporitesUndifferentiated
data.Description: Platform evaporites are made up of stratiform beds, usually<50 m thick and composed of stacked <1–5 m thick para-sequences or evaporite cycles, with a variably present restricted marine carbonate at its cycle base. The platform model deposits evaporites a few 10s of metres thick, that interfinger with shallow water siliciclastic and carbonate facies and their associated fauna and flora, including shoreface and sabkha facies. The shallow conditions and limited sediment accommodation space means that evaporitic drawdown produces brine levels only marginally below sea level. Therefore, there is minimal hydraulic potential for gravity-driven seepage of new seawater through a permeable seaward barrier.

data.Name: PlatformEvaporitesRamp
data.Description: Platform evaporites deposited along a ramp platform profile

data.Name: PlatformEvaporitesShelf
data.Description: Platform evaporites deposited along a shelf platform profile

data.Name: SlopeAndBasinEvaporitesUndifferentiated
data.Description: Basin wide evaporites are made up of thick evaporite units>50–100 m thick made up of varying combinations of deep-water and shallow water evaporites. They retain textural evidence of different but synchronous depositional settings,including mudﬂat, saltern, slope, and basin. The basin-wide model has its foundation on subsiding, attenuated crust. The accommodation space incorporated in this model is sufficient to explain many ancient, thick evaporites (500 m and more), in intracratonic basins or basins formed during the early stages of continental rifting. Water-brine depths  may be an order of magnitude greater those across platforms. Therefore, associated sedimentary facies will range from high energy shallow marine clastics, carbonates, and reworked evaporites, to slope and deep-basin mudrocks and redeposited coarse-grained sediments. There are no modern analogues for this type of basin; according to Warren (2016a) the Late Miocene (Messinian) Mediterranean drawdown is the latest example of basin-wide evaporites. Thick basin-wide deposits of gypsum and halite commonly act as detachments in thrust belts, and as halokinetic structures because of buoyancy contrasts with the surrounding strata.

data.Name: SlopeEvaporites
data.Description: Basin evaporites deposited along a slope profile

data.Name: BasinalEvaporite
data.Description: Basin evaporites deposited on the basin floor. Basinwide successions are usually dominated by thick massive salt beds (generally more than100 m thick), which are made up of stacked thick halite beds, but can also contain substantial volumes of thick-bedded Ca-sulphate and evaporitic carbonate, as in the intracratonic basinwide
